Change has been successfully merged
The build error is filed in https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/libpldm/+/67664
Please reference in the commit message the specification and section that the patch is implementing
Updated.
Done
I didn't see anything changed? From my quick look it adds the struct, just it's not annotated as packed (thanks).
Updated.
Done
Hi Thu, thanks for the patch and thanks for implementing the decoding in terms of the `msgbuf` APIs. I have some preliminary comments. I'll take a deeper look once they are resolved.

I'm not super keen on the `_unpkg` suffix. Can we drop it? Ideally none of these structs would be packed. We'll get there some day, but I don't want to do an API break to rename this one down the track.

There are many codes already use the struct name `pldm_numeric_effecter_value_pdr` in pldm repo:
https://github.com/openbmc/pldm/blob/master/libpldmresponder/pdr_numeric_effecter.hpp#L40
https://github.com/openbmc/pldm/blob/963c0fdf1aef305f266e00b2321fc244f89d0fa7/libpldmresponder/platform_numeric_effecter.hpp#L35
They required the `packed` struct (I think so). But we need the `unpack` struct in `decode_numeric_effecter_pdr_data` as `decode_numeric_sensor_pdr_data`.
That is the reason of adding `pldm_numeric_effecter_value_pdr_unpkg`.
What do you think?

If we already have a packed version of the struct let's just use that rather than add a new non-packed one. We'll have an ABI break twice otherwise. We can still use the `msgbuf` APIs to pack/unpack it - they handle with endianness as well.

I updated the code. `pldm_numeric_effecter_value_pdr_unpkg` is required inside of `decode_numeric_effecter_pdr_data` to avoid the errors such as
```
error: taking address of packed member of ‘struct pldm_numeric_effecter_value_pdr’ may result in an unaligned pointer value [-Werror=address-of-packed-member]
 2460 |         pldm_msgbuf_extract(buf, &pdr_value->terminus_handle);
      |                                  ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
```
Updated code.
Done
This is not `struct pldm_msg` because we've extracted the pointer to the PDR data buffer from a message elsewhere? Can you clarify that in the doxygen commentary?
Added.
See comment above.
This is mentioned earlier in the file, I think we can probably drop it.
Done
I'd prefer we drop "This commit". "Add the struct for the numeric effecter PDRs ..." is enough. Hopefully we can assume the commit message is talking about the commit itself 😊
Updated. I agree with you. I will remove `This commit` in the future patch set. 😄
Done
Nit: Please add a space after "table"
Done

Hi Thu, I have a few nitpicks, but also a concern around the doxygen comment for the new decode API. Further, if we already have the packed struct let's just keep using that and not add a new un-packed sibling.
Nit: space after "table"
I prefer you say what it _must be_ as well, not just what it's not. Something like "This must be a pointer to the PDR data in the GetPDR message body" or something equivalent.
Done
Done

Hi Thu, I've left a note about removing the `_unpkg` struct entirely. It's not the case that the `msgbuf` APIs _require_ a struct that isn't packed, rather the use of the `msgbuf` APIs allow us to _not require_ a packed struct (and this is better for correctness, portability, and performance).

Put another way, it's still fine to use the `msgbuf` APIs to extract data into a packed struct member.

The point I was trying to make on PS4 is that we can drop this completely. There should be no need to bounce through such a struct, instead we can decode straight into the `pdr_value` object passed in as a parameter, and avoid the copying at the bottom of the function.

Again the point I was trying to make was it's still important to use the `msgbuf` APIs here as the result will be endian-correct.
Updated code.
Done
Hi Thu, just a couple of nits and statements. Largely looks good. Thanks for the tests.
I've derived the same values myself.
Is this true? It's not immediately clear to me why it's correct. Can you unpack the reasoning?

. As description of `recordData ` in the table 68 
```
recordData:
PDR data bytes. This field is absent if responseCount = 0x0000. The number of PDR data bytes
returned in this field must match responseCount.
```
-> The statement will be true if the PDR is single part PDR (PDR data can be response in single GetPDRs commands).

If the PDR is multi-parts, the statement will be wrong.

I will remove the statement.

The `rff` parameter in `pldm__msgbuf_extract_range_field_format()` is the acronym of "range field format". You should probably use `ed` here (for "effecter data"). Or at least, something other than `rff`.
Updated.
I've verified the sizes and ordering in table 87 match what's described above.
Done
Can we use `pldm_msgbuf_destroy_consumed()`?
Done
Thanks Thu.
